brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the study is to evaluate an afterschool program to teach nutrition through
      basic cooking skills. This after school extracurricular program increases the students'
      confidence, knowledge, and skills for cooking as one of the first steps for dietary
      improvement. In addition to the life lessons students learn during this class, they gain
      self-confidence and become self-sufficient culinary experts that are capable of educating
      their siblings, parents, and social circles. This research project will test the impact this
      program has on nutritional knowledge, culinary efficacy, and nutritional choices made in and
      out of the home. The Pink and Dude Chef Afterschool Cooking Program was developed through
      STRIDE (Science through Translational Research in Diet and Exercise at California
      Polytechnic state University (Cal Poly) in San Luis Obispo, CA.

      Hypothesis: Middle school students participating in the Pink and Dude Chef afterschool
      cooking program will increase nutritional knowledge, culinary efficacy, motivation to eat
      fruits and vegetables, and fruit and vegetable intake compared to an attention control
      group.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Middle school aged child with parent willing to partcipate

          -  Ability to partipate in an afterschool program

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Less or greater than middle school aged

intervention.description: 12 educational cooking classes: two classes per week for six weeks (2 hours each)
intervention.intervention_name: Pink and Dude Chef Afterschool Cooking Program

facility.name: USDA Grand Forks Human Research Nutrition Center

clinical_study.official_title: Pink and Dude Chef Afterschool Cooking Program: Improving Food Knowledge and Skills in Middle School Students

primary_outcome.description: Baseline and post intervention measurements through questionnaires.
primary_outcome.measure: Questionnaire on nutritional knowledge, culinary efficacy, and motivation to eat fruit and vegetables
Palm scans (resonance Raman spectroscopy) to measure cartenoids (indicator of vegetable and fruit intake).

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

clinical_study.source: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

collaborator.agency: California Polytechnic State University-San Luis Obispo

lead_sponsor.agency: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center
